author: John Ficenec
title: Jeremy Corbyn's plans to renationalise UK power sector could cost taxpayer billions
text:
Saudi Arabia may go broke before the US oil industry buckles Jeremy Corbyn's plans to renationalise UK power sector could cost taxpayer billions Plans by the radical left-wing politician and aspiring Labour leader to take control of the country's gas and electricity sector could cost £185bn We need to reform the energy market Photo: PA Comments 
The cost to taxpayers of renationalising the UK's gas and electricity sector, as desired by aspiring Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, would total as much as £185bn, according to city experts. 
Peter Atherton, analyst at Jefferies investment bank, said that the cost to take control of just the UK assets of companies, which include British Gas owner Centrica and network operator National Grid, would drain about £124bn from the nation's coffers. 
Mr Corbyn has stated that he would nationalise British Gas, SSE, Eon, RWE, Npower, Scottish Power and EDF if he became Prime Minister in 2020. He said he would also put National Grid back into public hands. 
The veteran left-wing politician has made no secret of his admiration of Karl Marx and his plans to bring the gas and electricity supply back under government control. 
"Mr Corbyn suggests that the Government could take a majority equity stake in the utility companies," said Mr Atherton. 
"However, under stock exchange rules, once a stock holding hits 30pc an offer for the whole company must be made. Therefore, we assume that all of the equity would be acquired." 
London-listed energy group National Grid is the largest UK utility company with a market capitalistion of £32bn. It owns large gas and electricity supply assets along the US Eastern coast. 
Shares in the company, alongside the wider energy sector, fell today after the details of Mr Corbyn's plans were revealed in the Financial times. 
Mr Corbyn is rapidly gaining support to become the next Labour leader, but his radical, left-wing views have also put off many MPs and party members. 
As well as calling for the UK's assets to be nationalised, he has suggested printing money to pay for welfare, pushing up national insurance and corporation tax to fund free university education and grants and supports higher tax rates for the rich . Days until new Labour leader announced
